title-group.article-title: Item Discrimination and Type I Error in the Detection of Differential Item Functioning

author-notes.corresp: Yanju Li, Ohio University, 24 Home Street, No. 104, Athens, OH 45701, USA Email: yl323205@ohio.edu

abstract.p: In 2009, DeMars stated that when impact exists there will be Type I error inflation, especially with larger sample sizes and larger discrimination parameters for items. One purpose of this study is to present the patterns of Type I error rates using Mantel–Haenszel (MH) and logistic regression (LR) procedures when the mean ability between the focal and reference groups varies from zero to one standard deviation. The findings can be used as guides for alpha adjustment when using MH or LR methods when impact exists. A second purpose is to better understand the conditions that cause Type I error rates to inflate. The results indicate that inflation can be controlled even in the presence of large ability differences and with large samples.

body.p: The investigation of differential item functioning (DIF) has become an area of much interest in applied testing and methodological studies. DIF is said to exist when examinees with identical proficiency in two groups, traditionally labeled as reference group and focal group, perform differently on a given item after controlling for, or conditioning on, a measure of overall skill measured by the item (Dorans & Holland, 1993; Narayanan & Swaminathan, 1996). In many DIF analyses, the total test score is used as the measure of overall skill, and item performance is simply the proportion of persons having the item correct.

Researchers have put great effort into developing a variety of techniques to detect DIF, including parametric and nonparametric methods. Among the various methods, the Mantel–Haenszel (MH) procedure (Holland & Thayer, 1988; Mantel & Haenszel, 1959) and logistic regression (LR; Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990) are regarded as two of the most common statistical testing approaches in DIF analysis. Narayanan and Swaminathan (1996) pointed out that MH tests were “computationally simple, inexpensive, easy to implement in practice, and do not require large sample sizes” (p. 257). Moreover, the MH procedure provides an associated significance test (Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990, p. 361). LR can be considered as “an extension of the MH procedure that is effective in detecting both uniform and nonuniform DIF” (Rogers & Swaminathan, 1993, p. 105).

A main advantage of LR was that “it is a model-based procedure with the ability variable treated as continuous” (Narayanan & Swaminathan, 1996, pp. 257-258). It can also be easily applied (Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990). In recent years, the issue of Type I error rates of DIF detection using either the MH procedure or the LR procedure has attracted more and more researchers’ attention; Type I error inflation tends to be one of the important issues in DIF investigations in certain situations. Previous studies indicated that both the MH and LR procedures for detecting DIF work well (i.e., maintain expected Type I error rates) when the focal and reference groups are relatively equivalent in ability distribution (Roussos & Stout, 1996).

However, mean ability differences between the two groups often result in inflated Type I error in both the MH and LR techniques. The group ability difference is also termed impact (DeMars, 2010; Roussos & Stout, 1996). There have been a number of investigations focusing on the issue of Type I error inflation in MH and LR procedures when group ability differences exist. Zwick (1990) showed that we should expect inflated Type I errors with the MH procedure when the focal and reference groups differ in mean ability on the trait of interest unless the data follow a Rasch model or the test scores are highly reliable. Subsequent studies explored this further (e.g., Meredith & Millsap, 1992; Uttaro & Millsap, 1994). The significance of impact in the investigation of the Type I error rate is stated clearly by Roussos and Stout (1996):
It is important to note that in order for a matching criterion to be statistically appropriate, the problem of Type I error inflation due to impact must be successfully addressed. Otherwise, impact may cause the procedure to often indicate DIF even when none is present. (p. 216)

Güler and Penfield (2009) pointed out that there was Type I error rate inflation in LR under the condition of unequal ability distributions for the two groups. DeMars (2009) conducted a series of simulations that show the patterns of the Type I error inflation using MH and LR techniques under various conditions (e.g., different test length and sample size). However, all the discrimination parameters for items were relatively large. DeMars (2009) noted that “Type I error inflation (and power) is higher with higher discriminations” (p. 155). DeMars (2010) also indicated that when the focal and reference groups differ in ability (i.e., impact exists) there will be Type I error inflation and offered two potential explanations for this inflation: (a) the use of fallible, observed scores as the conditioning variable and (b) the impact of guessing.

One purpose of the present study is to investigate the patterns of Type I error rates using MH and LR procedures with simulated data when the mean ability between the focal and reference groups varies from zero to one standard deviation in a two-parameter (2PL) logistic item response theory (IRT) model. The resulting tables can then be used as guides for alpha adjustment when using MH or LR method when impact exists. Our second purpose is to more fully understand Type I error rates in 2PL model data and under varying item discriminations. That is, previous studies indicated that inflation of Type I error is less a concern in the one-parameter logistic (or Rasch) model for the MH procedure because the MH hypothesis is identical with the null hypothesis that there is no DIF when data follow a Rasch model (Holland & Thayer, 1988; Zwick, 1990). In this study we vary separately and jointly the magnitude and variation of the item discrimination parameter and evaluate the effect on Type I error with both the MH and LR procedures.

sec.title: The Mantel–Haenszel Procedure
sec.p: The Mantel–Haenszel procedure (Holland & Thayer, 1988) is based on contingency tables. Total scores for reference and focal group participants are divided into the same K scoring levels. The number of participants in these two groups and in kth score level can be displayed in a 2 × 2 contingency table (success or failure on the item is crossed with group, focal or reference; see Table 1).

caption.p: 2 × 2 Contingency Table for Mantel–Haenszel Procedure at kth Score Level

sec.p: The MH statistic is distributed as a chi-square with one degree of freedom. The pooled ratio equals the odds that examinees in the reference group respond to an item correctly to the odds of success for examinees of a comparable focal group. The formula used to compute MH odds ratio α is as follows:

where ak and bk indicate the number of participants with the kth score level in the reference group who answer the studied item correctly and wrongly, respectively; ck and dk indicate the number of participants with the kth score level in the focal group who answer the studied item correctly and wrongly, respectively; m1k and m0k indicate the total number of participants with the kth score level in both reference and focal groups who answer the studied item correctly and wrongly, respectively; nRk and nFk indicate the total number of participants with the kth score level who are in the reference and focal groups, respectively; and tk indicates the total number of participants within the kth score level (Dorans, 1989; Holland & Thayer, 1988).

The null hypothesis for the MH statistic is α = 1. When α is more than one, the advantage on the studied item is toward the reference group. On the contrary, when α is less than one, the advantage turns to the focal group (Dorans, 1989). The MH test statistic follows a χ2 distribution with one degree freedom and tests a null hypothesis of no DIF:
E(ak) and Var(ak) represent the expectation and the variance of ak, which can be computed by

sec.title: The Logistic-Regression Procedure
sec.p: The LR model can be expressed as

where U denotes the response to the given item, t denotes total score for participants, g denotes reference and focal group membership, and tg denotes the interaction between total score and group membership (Güler & Penfield, 2009; Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990).

When the null hypothesis is true, that is, there is no DIF, b2 and b3 should not be significantly different from zero; when b2 is not zero, uniform DIF exists; when b3 is unequal to zero, nonuniform DIF occurs in the studied item. LR is can be used to test both uniform DIF and nonuniform DIF.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: A Monte Carlo program evaluating the Type I error rates of the MH and LR procedures for uniform DIF detection was used in this study. Because the MH procedure is less effective or less powerful in detecting nonuniform DIF (Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990), Type I error comparisons with the more effective LR procedure would bias the results in favor of the MH procedure if we also sought to detect nonuniform DIF. Dichotomous item response data were simulated using a 2PL IRT model (Lord, 1980). All programming was done in R—a statistical programming language with a wide variety of statistical packages (see www.r-project.org). One of the most significant advantages of R is that its source code is freely available. Packages used in the study include CMC, irtoys, vcd, and difR, all of which are available through the normal procedures for downloading R packages for use with the program.

Many of the factors that have an impact on DIF detection have been discussed in earlier DIF investigations (e.g., Güler & Penfield, 2009; Jodoin & Gierl, 2001; Mazor, Clauser, & Hambleton, 1992; Narayanan & Swaminathan, 1996; Rogers & Swaminathan, 1993; Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990). First, sample size is a factor known to affect Type I error rates. Güler and Penfield (2009) identified N = 200 to 250 members in each group as the minimum sample size for adequate power in MH and LR procedures and N = 1,000 examinees in each group represented “conditions of relatively large sample size” (p. 322). Jodoin and Gierl (2001) used N = 250, 500, and 1,000 persons in each group for their simulation study to represent small, medium, and large sample sizes, respectively. In this study, three levels of sample size were selected. NR and NF denote the number of examinees of reference and focal groups, respectively. NR = NF = 300 represented a relatively small sample size, and NR = NF = 1,000 represented a relatively large sample size. NR = NF = 650 was also selected to examine the tendency of DIF detection performance for a certain sample size between a small and a large one.

Test length is a factor in DIF analyses because of the impact of the number of items on reliability and the influence this has on the precision of ability estimations (Narayanan & Swaminathan, 1996). Güler and Penfield (2009) simulated 60 items, Herrera and Gomez (2008) simulated 10 items, and DeMars (2009) simulated 20, 40, and 60 items. In this study, test length was set at 50 items, a moderate test length.

The distribution of mean differences is also considered a significant factor that can influence DIF detection (Jodoin & Gierl, 2001). Mean standardized ability differences between focal and reference groups were manipulated from 0.0 to 1.0 in increments of 0.1. The difficulty parameters for the items were randomly sampled from a uniform distribution (−2.0 to 2.0). The item discrimination parameters were fixed in different ranges, such as 0.2 to 2.0 or 1.2 to 2.0, with a uniform distribution for different analyses. Every cell in the simulation was replicated 10,000 times and the mean proportion of false rejections, or the Type I error rate, was recorded. Note that no items displaying DIF were created in this study because the research is focused on Type I error rate.

With 50 items, there will be 51 possible observed score levels (0 to 50). When the focal and reference groups differ in ability, there will often be very few persons from one group in the more extreme levels. One practical solution for this is to collapse scoring levels or to “thicken” the conditioning variable. Prior research indicates that group width for the matching variable may have an effect on the accuracy of DIF investigation. Raju, Bode, and Larsen (1989) conducted simulations to compare the performance of 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 score groups with a 40-item vocabulary test and claimed that “4 or more score groups yield stable α estimates with the MH technique” (p. 11). Donoghue and Allen (1993) studied multiple procedures for forming matching variables and concluded that “thick matching can increase stability and so decrease the variability of MH statistics, but it also increases statistical bias” (p. 135). However, Clauser, Mazor, and Hambleton (1994) found that Type I error was inflated when sample size was large, the number of score groups was extremely small, and the ability distributions were unequal. For our study, two types of thick matching—quintiles and deciles—were used for both DIF procedures in this study. LR was also evaluated using thin (i.e., raw score) matching, as were selected MH situations.

Item parameters and dichotomous item responses were simulated for the two groups using R functions. To verify the correctness of the R codes developed for this study, several single simulations of data for the MH and LR tests were analyzed in SPSS as well. The same results exhibited by SPSS and R confirmed the accuracy of the MH and LR tests obtained through our R Monte Carlo program.

sec.title: Simulation 1
sec.p: In the first simulation, the Type I error rates for the MH and LR procedures were examined when the raw score was used as the conditioning variable under both quintiles and deciles thick matching with sample sizes of 300, 650, and 1,000. Figure 1 and Figure 2 illustrate the results of the MH and LR procedures, respectively. The figures show that (with the increments of 0.1 on group ability difference) the inflated rejection rates are prone to increase independent of sample size and score group width. In addition, the inflation of the Type I error rate goes up when the sample size varies from small (N = 300) to large (N = 1,000) for the two procedures under the condition of both quintiles and deciles thick matching. It is important to note that in each of these simulations the studied item varied randomly; it was not a fixed item with specific characteristics. In particular, the studied item was simply the first of the randomly generated items for each simulation. All the results of this simulation were reasonably consistent with the findings of DeMars (2009). Note that the use of deciles for matching showed less inflation of Type I error rates than quintiles matching did when sample size was fixed, regardless of whether the sample size is large or small for both MH and LR techniques.

caption.p: The Type I error rates for MH procedure with 10,000 replications
Note: MH = Mantel–Haenszel; N300 = small sample size; N650 = medium sample size; N1000 = large sample size; 5g = quintiles; 10g = deciles.
The Type I error rates for LR procedure with 10,000 replications
Note: LR = logistic regression; N300 = small sample size; N650 = medium sample size; N1000 = large sample size; 5g = quintiles; 10g = deciles.

sec.p: Our findings were also consistent with previous research in that larger sample size and larger group ability discrepancy resulted in an inflation of the Type I error rates in MH and LR procedures (DeMars, 2009; Roussos & Stout, 1996). The potentially most troublesome conditions of 1,000 sample size and group impact of 1.0 were selected to examine the false rejection rates when the item discrimination parameters (for both the studied and nonstudied items) vary in different combinations.

sec.title: Simulation 2
sec.p: In this simulation, the range of the item discrimination parameter is manipulated to examine how the discrimination parameter affects the performance of the Type I error rates. The range varies from 0.2 to 1.7. Difficulty parameters were randomly selected from a uniform distribution and 1,000 examinees for each group are selected in this simulation. Again, the (randomly positioned) first item is selected as the studied item. Table 2 shows that the inflation of Type I error rates can be controlled within the nominal level of significance (.05) for the MH approach when the range of the item discrimination parameters for all the items is very small, such as 0.2 in this study. Compared with the MH approach, LR generally displayed slightly more inflated rejection rates, especially under the condition of deciles thick matching. This may be because some information is lost when thick matching is used. However, the inflation was controlled fairly well when the discrimination parameters have a small range; that is, in this case, all the rejection rates are close to the nominal level of significance. Where the range of the item discrimination parameters is very small (e.g., 0.2), the Type I error rate can be controlled quite well. Perhaps this is because of the similarity to the one-parameter model.

caption.p: The Type I Error Rates for MH and LR Procedures Under 1,000 Sample Size and Group Impact of 1.0

fn.p: Note: NR = sample size of reference group; NF = sample size of focal group; µd = group ability impact; a = discrimination parameter; MH = Mantel–Haenszel; LR_R = logistic regression using raw score; LR_10g = logistic regression using deciles thick matching.

sec.p: Zwick (1990) noted that higher discriminating items under conditions of impact would appear to show DIF favoring the group with higher ability distribution and items with lower discrimination would appear to show DIF favoring the lower ability group. The odds ratio is examined in this simulation, and the pattern shown in Figure 3 and Figure 4 is the relationship between the studied item discrimination parameter and the odds ratio for DIF under conditions of group impact of 0.0 and 1.0, respectively. Figure 3 shows that DIF does not appear to favor either group when there is no impact. On the contrary, Figure 4 indicates that generally the higher ability group is favored by the higher discriminating item and the lower ability group is favored by the lower discriminating item. These outcomes are consistent with Zwick (1990).

caption.p: The Mantel–Haenszel (MH) odds ratio when no impact exists between reference and focal groups
The Mantel–Haenszel (MH) odds ratio when impact exists between reference and focal groups

sec.p: If the discrimination parameters for all items are relatively large (greater than or equal to 0.8), the Type I error inflation again adheres closely to the nominal significance level and is independent of the range of discrimination parameter. Inflation occurs when low discriminating items are included in the model, especially under the condition of a wider range of discrimination parameters. For instance, the false rejection rates for MH equal 0.0804 and 0.0778 when discrimination parameters are in the range 0.2 to 1.8 and from 0.2 to 1.9, respectively. The performance of the LR procedure is similar. However, much of the corresponding inflation for the LR procedure is greater than that of the MH procedure.

The performance of the LR procedure with both thin matching (51 score groups with 50 items) and deciles thick matching can be compared in Table 2 for NR = NF = 1,000. The results are similar with only very small differences in the inflated Type I error rates. An identical analysis was conducted for the MH procedure, and the results over the 29 conditions shown in Table 2 showed somewhat less Type I inflation for thin matching than deciles. The mean difference was 0.0067, reaching a maximum of 0.0112 for the case in which a ranged from 1.3 to 1.8.

sec.title: Simulation 3
sec.p: Earlier investigations of DIF were often done with a fixed studied item. In our third simulation, the first item was fixed as the studied item and systematically varied from being an item with low discrimination to being an item with high discrimination (a = 0.2 to 2.0, respectively). Inflated false rejection rates for the two procedures, also under the condition of 1,000 sample size and group impact of 1.0, were noted. Table 3 presents the Type I error rates for both the MH and LR approaches when the discrimination parameter for the fixed studied item varied from 0.2 to 2.0. The discrimination parameters for the remaining 49 items were randomly selected from 0.2 to 1.8. The nonstudied items therefore had both low and high discrimination parameters in this simulation.

caption.p: The Type I Error Rates for MH and LR Procedures When the Studied Item Is Fixed and the NonStudied Items Include Items With Low Discrimination Indices

fn.p: Note: NR = sample size of reference group; NF = sample size of focal group; µd = group ability impact; a = discrimination parameter; MH = Mantel–Haenszel; LR_R = logistic regression using raw score, LR_10g = logistic regression using deciles thick matching.

sec.p: Type I error rates would appear to be controlled within the nominal α = .05 using the MH test when the value of discrimination parameter for the studied item was from 0.6 to 0.9. In contrast to MH, LR shows little to no inflation only in the situation where the discrimination parameter for the studied item is set from 0.8 to 0.9 when using raw score and from 0.6 to 0.7 when using deciles thick matching. Figure 5 illustrates that where a = 1.2 to 2.0, the MH test displays greater false rejection rates than did LR; in the portion of the figure with a = 0.2 to 0.8, it is the reverse.

caption.p: The Type I error rates for Mantel–Haenszel (MH) and logistic regression (LR) procedures when the studied item is fixed and nonstudied items include items with low discrimination parameters

sec.p: Table 4 shows the false rejection rates in the analogous condition except that the discrimination parameters for the nonstudied items now vary from 1.2 to 2.0. In this simulation, the Type I error rates for MH procedure adhered to nominal significance level when the discrimination parameter for the studied item varied from 0.7 to 1.6. There was slight inflation of Type I error as the discrimination parameter of the studied item increased from 1.6 to 2.0. For LR, most situations showed Type I error inflation except where the discrimination parameter for the studied item was set to 1.4 and 1.6 for raw score and 0.9 and 1.0 for deciles thick matching. Figure 6 indicates that inflation for LR is greater than that for the MH discrimination parameter for studied items with a less than 1.6 when the raw score is used as the conditioning variable. The use of deciles for the conditioning variable in LR function is in an opposite manner to this with a crossing point of approximately 1.2 for the studied item discrimination.

caption.p: The Type I Error Rates for MH and LR Procedures When the Studied Item Is Fixed and No Low Discrimination Items Are Included in Nonstudied Items

fn.p: Note: NR = sample size of reference group; NF = sample size of focal group; µd = group ability impact; a = discrimination parameter; MH = Mantel–Haenszel; LR_R = logistic regression using raw score; LR_10g = logistic regression using deciles thick matching.

caption.p: The Type I error rates for Mantel–Haenszel (MH) and logistic regression (LR) procedures when the studied item is fixed and the nonstudied items exclude low discriminating items

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study examined Type I error rates for the MH and LR procedures when sample size, item discriminations, and impact varied and the conditioning variable was thickened. The results from our simulations were reasonably in agreement with those of early studies and extended our knowledge of the problem.

First, Simulation 1 showed that larger sample sizes and larger ability distribution differences are prone to inflated Type I error rates in both MH and LR procedures. This is consistent with Roussos and Stout (1996) and DeMars (2009). Moreover, Simulation 1 suggested that deciles matching displays less inflation of Type I error rates than quintiles matching does independent of sample size for both MH and LR techniques. This is in agreement with Clauser et al. (1994).

Second, Simulation 2 illustrated that it would appear that there are a number of factors that influence the Type I error rate of both MH and LR procedures in addition to sample size and group mean difference in ability (impact). The discrimination indices of both the studied and nonstudied items (the context for the studied item) are an issue. When all item discriminations are very similar (or when the Rasch model is likely to provide a good fit to the data), Type I inflation does not appear to be as serious an issue as when the item discriminations vary substantially. The actual values of the discrimination indices may be larger or smaller with little effect on Type I error as long as the discrimination indices are relatively homogeneous. That is, the range of the discrimination parameters matters. In addition, the pattern of odds ratios shows that when the studied item has larger discrimination, the odds ratio tends to be larger than 1, which in our case means that the DIF favors the higher ability group. These findings are in agreement with Zwick (1990).

Although previous studies (e.g., DeMars, 2009) have indicated that item discrimination parameters have an effect on the Type I error inflation, no single article has systematically investigated the effect of various discrimination indices. In this study, Table 2 showed the context effect of the value of the discrimination indices of the nonstudied items on Type I inflation of a randomly selected item. Inflation was not nearly so serious an issue when all discrimination indices were greater than or equal 0.8.

The value of the discrimination parameter of the studied item was also relevant to Type I error inflation. Figure 5 indicated that when the studied item discrimination was in the range from 0.6 to 0.9, Type I error inflation was well controlled even when the nonstudied items had rather heterogeneous discriminations. As the discrimination of the studied item moved away from the 0.6 to 0.9 ranges, either lower or higher, Type I inflation increased rather abruptly.

Yet Figure 6 shows that when the nonstudied items had discrimination indices between 1.2 and 2.0, the Type I error inflation was adequately controlled for studied items in the very same range. Because item parameter estimates, including discrimination, can be readily estimated, it may be reasonable to do this prior to DIF analyses in situations where there is large impact to see whether Type I error inflation is a concern. This interaction of studied-item discrimination and context (the discriminations of the nonstudied items) was only studied carefully in a most problematic case where the focal and reference group mean difference in ability was 1.0 and sample sizes were large. Because Type I inflation is not as serious an issue for less extreme group differences and with smaller sample sizes, the interaction is much more complex than just one of item-context. As a final observation, we will note that it appears that both MH and LR will suffer more Type I error inflation when coarser values used for the conditioning variable. This is somewhat tentative because we investigated only quintiles and deciles in these simulation studies. Yet it is unfortunate because larger group mean differences may encourage the use of a coarser scale with the MH procedure. LR with a finer conditioning variable may be a more viable option in such situations.
